report_title: Forensic Technology Services in the US
executive_summary: Demand for forensic technology service providers depends on investment from state, county, municipal and the federal government. Since government agencies are essentially the primary market for services, many forensic crime labs rely heavily on tax revenue and robust crime budgets for agencies to outsource work to them. Public spending surged during the pandemic as the federal government sought to prevent the US economy from falling into a massive recession, raising revenue in 2020 and 2021. As these expenditures lapsed as COVID-19 ended, funds for forensic technology labs slowed, causing revenue to lag in 2022 and 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Shifts in Government Spending Have Fostered Significant Volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since the large majority of the industry's providers are public agencies, government spending is the primary determinant of demand for forensic technology service companies. Agencies received lots of funding during COVID-19 as the federal government engaged in massive deficit spending to prevent a major economic collapse. Since many public organizations were flush with cash, they boosted their investment in forensic technology services, causing revenue to shoot up in 2020 and 2021. As the pandemic ended, COVID-19 era aid expired, while state and local governments concerned about high deficits slashed their spending. Since government investment fell, investment in forensic technology services dropped, causing revenue to depress in 2022 and 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Adoption of High-Tech Biometrics Technology Has Benefited the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Although declining funding from some state and local governments has challenged providers, the growing importance of forensic evidence in criminal investigations has made the industry's services indispensable. Much of the recent growth for forensic technology service companies has stemmed from the introduction of high-tech biometrics technology. Advances in DNA analysis have enabled forensic science technicians to extract larger quantities of valuable data from smaller DNA samples.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Market Share Concentration Has Dropped as the Number of Labs Has Expanded
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The number of establishments has increased during the current period as the adoption of new technologies has encouraged new providers to enter the industry and capture new revenue streams. As more providers have entered the industry, market share concentration has dropped. Specifically, the number of private forensic laboratories has risen significantly.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Slumping Crime Rate Will Drive Down Demand and Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As elevated economic growth during the outlook period raises per capita disposable income, corporate profit and tax revenue, government spending and funding for forensic laboratories will expand, aiding the industry. Higher government spending can increase the amount of outsourced work these governments can afford and increase their in-house forensic capabilities, spurring demand for the industry's services. Despite these developments, the crime rate will continue to drop because of the aging of the US population and higher education rates, fostering a decline in revenue in the years leading up to 2029.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Tackling the Backlog Will Insulate the Industry From Steeper Revenue Declines
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The need to substantially reduce and maintain the backlog of forensic evidence, particularly DNA samples, will limit lags in demand during the outlook period. According to the US Department of Justice (DOJ), publicly funded crime labs had nearly one million backlogged requests in 2020 (latest data available) that needed to be completed.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Changes in the Industry's Structure Will Persist
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since technological change will play a significant role across most services, advances in forensic biology will make DNA and latent print testing two of the fastest-growing services. As a result, the industry is expected to encounter diversified revenue streams during the outlook period.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry provide database forensics and testing services, such as biometrics, fingerprinting and DNA testing. Other testing services include forensic biology, forensic toxicology immunoassay (drug testing), testing for controlled substances and ballistics testing using analytical instruments.

positive_impact_factors: high - steady Barriers To Entry Level

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Local and state government investment

key_trends: The primary form of competition is location and service quality.
Operators with an ASCLD/LAB accreditation typically encounter greater service demand than labs without the accreditation.
Providers face competition from universities and research centers.
Technological advances have contributed to higher revenue for forensic technology service companies.
The slumping crime rate will reduce service demand for the industry's services during the outlook period.

market_segmentation.segment_description: State governments are the primary market for the industry, comprising nearly half of revenue.
Demand from county governments comprise nearly one-quarter of revenue.
In 2024, the federal government comprises the smallest share of demand for forensic technology services.
Municipal governments account for the third-largest segment in the industry.

products_and_services.product_description: Controlled substances analysis involves identifying drugs and other substances, the possession of which is sometimes restricted by the government.
Toxicology services refer to the analysis of biological samples for the presence of drugs and other toxic materials.
Latent print services involve friction ridge analysis concerning latent fingerprints, palm prints and footprints.
Firearms services include the examination of pattern evidence resulting from the use of these weapons.
Beyond these services, other forms of assistance offered by providers pertain to digital evidence, questioned documents and impressions services.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Local and state government investment represents the total money allocated by local and state governments.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the largest concentration of forensic technology companies.
The West contains the second largest number of establishments.
The Mid-Atlantic region has a high concentration of federal agencies and government contractors.

regulations_points.regulation_description: To gain and maintain ASCLD/LAB accreditation, forensic laboratories must accept regular inspections of their facilities.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE HEALTH INSURANCE PORTABILITY AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT (HIPAA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: HIPAA mandates the safeguarding of sensitive patient information.
FRE determines how digital evidence can be used in U.S. courts.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
High level of technology change increases barriers to entry.
Accreditations like ASCLD/LAB present barriers with requirements for periodic reviews, testing and inspections.
Ability to secure funding from public agencies for accredited forensic labs is a barrier.
Standing out requires unique value propositions and innovative solutions to compete with seasoned players.
Securing access to highly skilled workforce of analysts and examiners is critical.

basis_points.basis_title: Location and service quality are primary forms of competition
basis_points.basis_description: Operators with an ASCLD/LAB accreditation typically encounter greater service demand than labs without the accreditation.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition from universities and research centers
basis_points.basis_description: This rivalry can foster significant advancements in relevant tools and techniques, driving innovation and efficiency within the industry.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Forensic technology companies aren't particularly consolidated as most forensic labs are supported by government agencies and serve local markets.
High start-up costs and accreditation requirements prevent some entry, boosting concentration somewhat.
Concentration varies based on government branch providing funding, with higher fragmentation at state/local levels.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages represent forensic technology service companies' largest expense, making up more than half of revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Expand as Providers Modernize Their Technology
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Laboratory purchases include capital expenditures for new and renovated laboratory facilities and various instruments, robotics and computers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue Volatility is Derived Primarily From Government Funding
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue is mainly derived from government agency funding. Revenue is most sensitive to fluctuations in federal and state funding.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fixed Government Budgets Limit Funding for Providers
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fixed government budgets restrict how agencies can fund forensic technology service companies.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ADVANCED TOOLS AND TECHNOLOGY HAVE BENEFITED FORENSIC TECHNOLOGY SERVICE PROVIDERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advanced digital tools and technology have significantly benefited forensic technology service providers by enhancing their software solutions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: PROVIDERS HAVE ENCOUNTERED IMPROVEMENTS IN OPERATING EFFICIENCY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Research and development (R&D) is critical for forensic technology service companies.

FAQs.question: Does your company rely heavily on demand from a single, key market?
FAQs.answer: Players provide services for a wide range of federal, local and private customers.

FAQs.question: How does your company target key potential markets?
FAQs.answer: Labs partner with local, state and federal entities to be the primary provider of testing services.

FAQs.question: What is your company's most significant operational expense?
FAQs.answer: Because of the nature of the industry, wages are the most significant expense for the average company.

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need?
FAQs.answer: Laboratories are often based near healthcare providers.

FAQs.question: Has investment in new technologies increased your company's competitiveness?
FAQs.answer: Technological developments in this industry have increased the speed of processes and automated manual processes.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to minimize/reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Skilled and knowledgeable workers are required for most work in this industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company benefit (either directly or indirectly) from any government legislation?
FAQs.answer: Companies benefit indirectly from changes in government consumption and investment.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Labs must be cautious when handling samples to avoid giving false test results.

FAQs.question: How has your company raised profit?
FAQs.answer: Profitability increases for the average player since many firms charge a premium for their services.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new capital equipment?
FAQs.answer: The level of depreciation may vary from laboratory to laboratory.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? What qualifications must your staff have?
FAQs.answer: Given the highly sensitive and technical nature of the industry's services, access to experienced examiners is crucial.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating areas?
FAQs.answer: Forensic technology companies compete heavily based on geographical location.

FAQs.question: What accreditation does your company have? If none, how would it benefit you to gain accreditation?
FAQs.answer: To secure consistent demand for their services, laboratories must become accredited.

FAQs.question: How do you track the incarceration rate? How is your business affected by rising or falling incarceration rates?
FAQs.answer: When the number of criminal investigations increases, demand for forensic evidence processing increases.

FAQs.question: How do you track the crime rate? How is your business affected by rising or falling crime rates?
FAQs.answer: When the crime rate rises, especially the number of violent crimes, the amount of forensic evidence that needs to be processed increases.

FAQs.question: How much revenue is generated through projects completed because of funding from local and state governments? How will you take advantage of this?
FAQs.answer: Since governments at the state and local levels represent the vast majority of revenue, increased spending at these levels positively affects funding for forensic laboratories.
